tacker/sol_refactored/api/wsgi.py.message:
If the Content-type is other than "application/json", it is better to return 406 according to SOL013.
-----
406 Not Acceptable: 
If the "Accept" HTTP header does not contain at least one name of a content type
that is acceptable to the API producer, the API producer shall respond with this
response code.
-----

It may be convenient to use "Accept.acceptable_offers" for the judgment.
https://docs.pylonsproject.org/projects/webob/en/stable/api/webob.html
(ex.nova code　https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py#L99-L100)

Yes.
Now, even if we set Accept other than "application/json" in create API, it will return the response by setting Content-Type to "application/json".
This is not just a V2 specification, so it seems good to consider fixing it with another patch in the future.
Thanks.

barbican/tests/plugin/test_castellan_sec.message:
This is certainly a bug in the VaultSecretStore.  I think it's a mistake to defer generation of symmetric keys to the castellan key_manager directly because they result inconsistent encodings and there is no way to tell which is what.

I think a complete fix for this issue should include changes to VaultSecretStore to ensure that generated keys are stored in the same way as keys stored via the API.  We should not have to guess what format is stored in the DB.

To be extra thorough, we may want to consider adding a new column/meta value to effectively version the data we're storing so we can be confident we only store things in a single format moving forward. (Maybe we need to revisit the OVO patches?)

barbican/plugin/castellan_secret_store.p.message: I'm not sure it's quite that simple - before the fix most secrets are b64 encoded, but keys generated by castellan are not.

I think it's a fairly straightforward check here.  If the meta doesn't have a version, then we know it was stored prior to this fix.

For most secrets, that means the payload is already base64 encoded, so we can just stuff it into the DTO (which must be encoded).  The tricky part is figuring out which ones are not base64 encoded because they were generated by Castellan.

One important detail that can help us tell the difference is that orders require the bit length of the key you're generating.  So, generated secrets always have a bit length.

With that in mind, the logic should be:

* if it has no version, and no bit length, then it was not generated and it is already b64 encoded.

* if it has no version, and does have a bit length, then it may or may not be encoded.  By definition base64 encoding expands the data.  So, if the actual length of the payload is longer than the bit_length specified, then it is already base64 encoded.  If the actual length matches the bit_length, then we know we have plaintext and need to b64-encode before putting it in the DTO.
Ok, I think that should work.
Why not check the type here rather than trying to infer from the bit length?
Finally had some time to discuss with Ade (the other active core),  he agrees that type checking would be better here.  I'll update the patch with type checks here instead.

Talked to Ade about this as well.  We probably don't need to worry about this scenario, as this patch will ensure that the meta_dict will either have the metadata or not.  We can revisit this if/when we add a new metadata dict version in the future.  I'm going to remove the last clause from this if statement.

This is the project ID for cinder's internal use to cache images.  It must be configured for the 'image-volume-cache-enabled' feature.  Note: the OpenStack project for the ID must be created separately as setting this does not create it.

This is OpenStack user ID for cinder's internal use.  It must be configured for the 'image-volumne-cache-enabled' feature.  Note: the OpenStack user must be created separately as setting this does not create it.

templates/inspector_dnsmasq_http.erb.message:
Apparently my comment never posted through, my apologies.

I'm not a fan of adding more configuration options to puppet-ironic in the name of making everything which may be a slight behavior change of a back-end service we use maintain behavior. The important aspect is the overall contract for the end user. "Able to deploy" being that end contract.

Granted, the continued use of the option *does* mean a in-depth analysis of logs might take an extra 20 minutes when that comes up, but operators shouldn't realistically have to identify they have to change their configuration to handle the outlier when what they are worried about is things "just working".

I guess, ultimately, I'd prefer we go on a path of removing options wherever possible which don't bring operational value other than meaning the first 20 minutes of a log analysis is slightly more organized until it is no longer sequential as some leases are being retained.

config options are cheap. And if it's ever needed to turn off for some unforeseen future case it's better to have it with default enable not not have it at all.  Unfortunately with openstack and it's thousands of configuration options this is just something we have to deal with.  There are many times where we can't see when an end user might want to disable this (because we don't know all the use cases) and not having the option ends up with manual hacks and idempotency problems.  That being said if we don't think this should bother to be set, just remove it.

I agree that adding this option doesn't give much benefit.

One concern with just removing the option is that the change would not agree with what we care during backport "in case you'll backport this". We generally avoid making the forceful change in parameters in stable branches unless the previous configuration is completely broken, to avoid changing behavior and restarting services during update as much as possible.

However adding a redundant parameter doesn't make much sense here and this configuration affects only the tiny dnsmasq service so I don't expect big disruption cased by restarting the service.

So I'm good as long as the change is properly documented in a release note.

Right, I agree with Julia. This option does not really bring value.
If there are no objections I will update this change to remove 'dhcp-sequential-ip' from inspector dnsmasq configuration instead of making it optional.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/cert_mon/cer.message:
I think this change makes sense.
One unrelated thing..  does this code check (or care) if the subcloud is managed?
I noticed that the watcher checks this before it makes subcloud status updates

At this point in the audit, the audit doesn't care if the subcloud is managed (it does care that it is online, and has checked above). The idea is that we want to have an ongoing audit for certificate renewals regardless of management state. A subcloud may be unmanaged for some reason but we still want to ensure the certificates don't expire.

That said, yes, the watcher is checking for managed state (in DCIntermediateCertRenew:action_failed). I'm not sure of the day-one reason for this. However, note that within 24 hours of the watch failure, the full subcloud audit (part of this code we're looking at right here) will be kicked, and it will trigger the out-of-sync.

I think the behaviour here is okay for now, but we may want to consider that check for managed in DCIntermediateCertRenew:action_failed at some point.

Are items in queue in order of next_audit_timestamp? otherwise the for loop will exit without iterating all of the ready for processing items?

Yes, this is the essence of the PriorityQueue. I'm inserting to the queue using a tuple (timestamp, sc_audit_data), which means it is ordered by that initial timestamp value in the tuple.

The premise of this queue is that subclouds are prioritized in the queue by when they should next be audited. The check here means that none of the subclouds in the queue are ready to be audited (i.e. none yet match up against the current time).

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/cert_mon/sub.message: Broad question here: Is this something that should be made generic that could be applicable to reusing for other parts of code? Or is the code very specific to subcloud audit queuing and cannot be generalized?

Are you referring to all the classes in this file? I think so. 

I'd say that the generalized part is really the eventlet.PriorityQueue. I'm really only making some minor additions on top of that here: 1) adding an audit_count, and 2) tracking the subcloud name under audit within the PriorityQueue. 

Those changes seem fairly specialized to this part of the codebase, so I'm not sure it's worth trying to pull things out for further generalization. Does this make sense to you or am I missing something?
Not sure is there are use cases where an enqueue() is called with allow_requeue = True. If so, will removing the subbcloud a problem if there are multiple queued items for that subcloud?

The case where enqueue is called with requeue = True comes when a watch fires. In that case we allow the audit to be re-enqueued because there may have been a change in the certificate that the audit may possibly miss (a timing issue).

However, note that the list.remove() will only remove the first entry from the list. The second entry will be preserved, which is what we want in this case.

The dnsmasq process launches and attempts to manage the capabilities it has access to before dropping. I'm unsure if it is all or nothing, but some forum posts suggest all or nothing. deployment/ironic/ironic-pxe-container-p.message:
I think we should add --conf-file=/dev/null to ensure dnsmasq does not end up reading a default configuration file. To avoid issues like below.

[root@server ~]# cat /etc/dnsmasq.conf
log-dhcp
port=0

dhcp-host=00:84:ed:01:00:10,tag:dhcpv6,client.localdomain,[2001::20],[2001::21],[2001::22],[2001::23]
dhcp-range=set:range0,2001::10,2001::100,64,10m
dhcp-sequential-ip
# dhcpv6s for Client System Architecture Type (61)
dhcp-match=set:efi6,option6:61,0007
dhcp-match=set:efi6,option6:61,0009
dhcp-match=set:efi6,option6:61,0011
dhcp-option=tag:efi6,option6:bootfile-url,tftp://[2001::2]/shimx64.efi


[root@server ~]# dnsmasq -k --port=0 --enable-tftp --tftp-root=/var/lib/tftpboot/

dnsmasq: failed to bind DHCPv6 server socket: Address already in use

I find tftp logs to be useful, especially as a first indication that your node is alive and can reach the controller.

Can this log to a file like the inspector dnsmasq[1], so the following:

  --log-facility=/var/log/ironic/dnsmasq.log

will result in a log file available on the undercloud at /var/log/containers/ironic/dnsmasq.log

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/deployment/ironic/ironic-inspector-container-puppet.yaml#L432

cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/r.message:
suppose if there is as new volumename_template that allows displayname length >37, there is a chance for reduced vol_id characters count in the name.

we just ensure that minimum of 8 characters of volid is part of aux change volume name.

If we are sure that there will no other template used by customer, we can ignore this check.

This seems like something that warrants a log message, certainly INFO and maybe WARNING.

I don't see any existing code that limits the length of Storwize volume names. Why is this (replication setup) the first place where the limit is being enforced? I guess what I'm asking is, are there other places where the limit should also be enforced?

Sure, will be adding a LOG message stating the reason.
Regarding the code-changes specific to only (replication setup), the volumes names are framed by concatenation of constant(i.e, from storwize_const.py) and vref['name'].

We used to consider the default vref['name'] that we get from (<class 'cinder.objects.volume.Volume'> ), But our client has been using a custom-name template(i.e,being defined at cinder.CONF) rather to default-name.

Hence, after quite a good amount of testing and analysis we could conclude that, "target_change_vol_name" is the only variable prone to exceed the supported limit of our storage.

Although this could be worded more clearly, I think this is saying the custom name template will ensure the vref['name'] includes a UUID, and therefore truncating the name should not result in a naming collision with another volume.

This could definitely be worded more clearly.  As far as I can tell, this is what's going on:

The 'name' on the Volume object is generated, not stored, and there doesn't seem to be any length restriction on it (because it's in the config file, not the database).  The generated name is template + string representation of a UUID, and the calling function is slapping on two 4 char prefixes in front of that.  Since 36+8=44, if the config template is longer than 19 chars, we'll exceed the max length limitation of Storwize.

The problem I see with the approach taken in this function is that if there's a long template and we simply take the first 63 chars like at line 167, all the target_change_vol_name could wind up being the same.  I don't know if that's an issue or not (that is, it might not be a problem for the storage system, but if people are using these names for anything, customers will complain).

What you might want to do is ignore the target_vol_name and instead pass the vref['name'] directly to this function.  Then do something like:

   MAX_LEN = 63   # use a better name and add this to storwize_const
   useful_chars = MAX_LEN - len(storwize_const.REPLICA_AUX_VOL_PREFIX + storwize_const.REPLICA_CHG_VOL_PREFIX)
   return "%(chg)s%(aux)s%(name)s" % {'chg': storwize_const.REPLICA_CHG_VOL_PREFIX,
'aux': storwize_const.REPLICA_AUX_VOL_PREFIX, 'name': name[-useful_chars:]}

This way, you'll preserve the current prefixes and also the UUUID, which will contain all the randomness to keep all of these different.

neutron/agent/l3/dvr_local_router.py.message: What about 0.0.0.0/0 to allowed address pair? Mission impossible...

You are both right. Given that and also the fact that in ML2/OVN behaviour is similar (VIPs given as whole CIDR don't works properly and single IP addresses has to be configured to make it working) I changed that patch.
In fact the only improvement done here is that now it will not put ugly stacktrace in L3 agent's logs when CIDR is given as allowed_address_pair.

Although this is a valid entry (same as 1.0.0.0/8 for example), any allowed address pair with a mask smaller to 16 (that implies 64K addresses), should be limited. Of course, this limit should be discussed. But the point is that we can't provide this functionality, with the current architecture, for such big CIDRs and we need to raise a warning for this.

I see the problem here and I agree that this could be the solution.

My concern here: what if allowed_address_pair['ip_address'] is a /16 CIDR? That means 64K addresses. That will (1) take a lot of time and (2) will overpopulate the ARP table.

I tested with cidr='192.168.50.0/18' (16K addresses).

It took 24 secs in my env. I changed a bit "neutron.privileged.agent.linux.ip_lib.add_neigh_entry" to accept CIDRs instead of IPs. So, in one single privsep call, we iterate over the CIDR IPs adding the ARP register. With that chaage, my env took 13 secs to finish.

Besides, so many arp entry in network namespace may need to change related Linux kernel parameters. Otherwise, the kernel will consume a lot of computing time in ARP GC [1]. Then, all routers in this agent may get influenced.

[1] https://linux.die.net/man/7/arp
Just a question: what about to care of big CIDRs? As commented in PS1. With big CIDRs, that will take too much time and resources to write so many ARPs entries.

I think I was thinking in PS1, not this version. I agree with this and the follow up patch documenting this limitation: only /32 allowed address pairs will be populated in the ARP table of the local routers. It is understandable.

It's exactly how Pavlo wrote - only /32 IPs are added to the arp table in router's namespace. I think that this will not have any performance impact and will just avoid ugly failure in case when bigger cidr is added to port's allowed_address_pairs.
@Pavlo - done

Rodolfo, in this version of patch, only the single IP or single address CIDRs will be added as arp entries, so size of a CIDR is not a concern
AFAIU we will update docs etc to specifically state that only such CIDRs are supported for allowed address pairs in DVR

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Please consider the following:

Fix idrac-wsman set_power_state to wait on HW

The idrac-wsman power interface implementation's set_power_state()
method has returned to the caller immediately after issuing the out-of-
band (OOB) command to the Dell EMC integrated Dell Remote Access
Controller (iDRAC), without confirming the system has reached the
requested state. That is inconsistent with the ipmi and redfish
implementations, which synchronously wait until they have read back the
desired state before returning. This change fixes idrac-wsman
set_power_off() to wait like them.

That bug can cause instance workload deployments to fail on Dell EMC
PowerEdge server models on which IPA ramdisk soft power off fails. When
that occurs, ironic employs OOB power control as a fallback strategy.
During an otherwise successful deployment and activation, the subsequent
processing to power on and boot the baremetal node into the instance
operating system (OS) does not occur. Ironic treats the system in the
midst of powering off as already on, so it does not OOB power it on. A
show of the node does not report an error occurred; it is active, as
expected, but powered off. That breaks subsequent instance workflows
which expect the system to be powered on into the OS.

You are most welcome. Here is a shorter suggestion. Entirely your call :)

The idrac-wsman power interface's set_power_state() has returned to the
caller immediately after issuing the out-of-band (OOB) command to the
Dell EMC iDRAC, without confirming the system has reached the requested
state. This fixes that by synchronously waiting until the target state
has been read before returning.

That bug can cause instance workload deployments to fail on Dell EMC
PowerEdge server models on which IPA ramdisk soft power off fails and
ironic employs its OOB fallback strategy. After an otherwise successful
deployment, the node is active, but is powered off. No error is reported
in last_error. If the subsequent instance workflow expects the system to
be powered on into the operating system, it fails.

thanks, updated and found a way to make it even shorter. Here in commit messages I assume some familiarity with and knowledge about ironic and baremetal realm otherwise repeating the same thing over and over again in git log becomes repetitive. There is story link for those who need more context.

thanks for suggestion. I would be looking at making it shorter. E.g., information such as "That is inconsistent with the ipmi and redfish implementations, which synchronously wait until they have read back the desired state before returning." is nice to know and could be moved to linked story.

    tcp_lower = constants.PROTOCOL_TCP.lower()
    if (listener.peer_port, tcp_lower, "0.0.0.0/0") not in updated_ports:

specs/stein/upgrade-ansible-without-mist.message: what about UI and progress bars tracking the update/upgrade completion? If removed from UI, CLI perhaps should maintain some feature parity with that.
not necessarily related to the spec, but the stack update is not actually a noop? The stack is updated according to Heat, just nothing is applied to the nodes. Is that accurate?

i agree somewhat that zaqar and mistral can be complex. However, the proposed solution aims to just sidestep that issue by taking the approach to just not use the API.

I can't totally support that. Are there other things we could do fix these issues in the API? Shouldn't we be doing that so that all API interfaces are fixed?

Because the problems you allude to around complexity with debugging and queue issues apply to any API usage, not just that for update/upgrade.

Are we basically saying with this spec, that we'll allow not using the API if it's too complex?

This seems like a dangerous message and precedent to set.

I'm agree in general.
Just few things:
Its not a matter due the fact that its too complex (too complex to implement, too complex for developer), but a matter of user experience. The complexity is for the user who have to debug and understand how and where he should look at, to find the potential issues..

Tailing a subprocess call through a queue in a async way is not imho a classic API usage.
Seems like this could easily be fixed. One example, just tail the ansible.log file.

For deployment they can, because a script is written out as /var/lib/mistral/overcloud/ansible-playbook.sh 

Seems like this could be easily fixed.

I don't totally agree with this position. For any software project, someone could say that the API shouldn't be used because it's add a layer of indirection.

That's the whole point of API's. While I do agree that mistral/zaqar are quite complex, I don't fully support just not using the API for that reason.

Yes true, I agree but we use Ansible with the linux binary that we execute in a shell.
We don't call ansible with the API in Python or something.
That's the small difference we have in this case in TripleO VS "any software project", imho.

I'm totally "pro" using API and standard call in general, my feeling  with this part of TripleO is that we are not really in a classic usage.
why are these links called metalsmith? what does this have to do with metalsmith?
initially I didn't use the zaqar queue for config-download. The CLI just tail'd the ansible.log file that was being written by the mistral action.

Yes, I did some small improvement recently in the ooo-common and ooo-cli to address this "alternatives" solution after some discussion with UI folks.
I think the whole feeling for user experience has been improve with those reviews. (I can list them here if needed)
we should state that impacts the deprecated UI

Do we mean AWX (Tower) here?  (Otherwise i don't follow how is this option different from what we already have.)

Also, should this part move into "Alternatives"? AFAICT what you're proposing in the patches is only the first option (running Ansible directly), right?

For running Ansible directly, we should add drawbacks here:

* The update/upgrade commands must be run from a machine which can reach the overcloud machines via ssh, most often that would be the undercloud. Previously it was common to run the commands from undercloud, but it was not a requirement (having undercloud API access and t-h-t contents was enough).

* If operator's ssh session drops when they're running the upgrade, the upgrade will break. We should amend all docs to run the upgrade commands in a tmux/screen session.

* Update/upgrade workflows diverge from deployment workflows.

I'm presently -1 on this spec because of the last point. I think we should have a discussion with DF and pick a common approach for running Ansible. IMO consistency should be prioritized over simplicity of individual parts.
Maybe we should amend this spec to cover also deployment CLI (not just update/upgrade), and collaborate with someone from DF on the implementation?

glance/common/wsgi_app.py.message: Any wsgi container will generally be recycling workers after max_requests (or equivalent) which means that if they all run this, they will get their timers evenly distributed, and provide an interval of roughly N/$workers instead of what they actually configured. If they configure an interval of 60 minutes and 30 workers (which would not be crazy) then there will be a lot more activity than they expect, and they may be consuming a ton of resources if there are lots of images to download.

This would be very confusing for anyone with custom flavors or anyone running 'keystone+caching' as they would not be having prefetcher running.

We really should look if the CONF.image_cache_dir exists rather than looking for specific flavour name. That config option gets registered by the cache middleware and does not rely on hardcoded flavor name to work.
This should be fixed in different patch as we need to make similar change in glance/cmd/api.py as well.

I don't understand what the strict setting is for.  If this works without it, we should just remove it.

If docker and podman don't work without it, we shouldn't have a config setting, we should just do it.

It sounds like we just need to re-test everything with the obob fix only and if it works, just remove this.

In the latest changeset I have removed the strict setting and made it reject layers with no size.

To confirm this is safe, I have done traces pushing with both docker and podman.  the mitmproxy traces of communcation between podman/docker and this change are

http://people.redhat.com/~iwienand/zuul-registry/808621.docker.trace.log
http://people.redhat.com/~iwienand/zuul-registry/808621.podman.trace.log

In both we can see they are setting the size on layers correctly in the manifest

I think we might need the blob HEAD request size fix (https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul-registry/+/808622/2) to land before removing the fixup. I agree though that we should probably remove strict entirely and as long as the HEAD fix lands first we can also avoid setting the size here and always raise the error?

Then if we find new clients that struggle with this we can go back to toggling the behavior?

The HEAD blob size seemed to related to the size docker sets in the manifest -- this check was the size in layers. to be super clear

 {
  "schemaVersion": 2,
  "mediaType": "application/vnd.docker.distribution.manifest.v2+json",
  "config": {
    "mediaType": "application/vnd.docker.container.image.v1+json",
    "digest": "sha256:3da412d7f9f9add96458d18b4f4d00cea22170f01dcaee39a2660991ce1d2b2d"
     <---- MISSING SIZE HERE RELATED TO HEAD BLOB FIX ---->
  },
  "layers": [
   {
     "mediaType": "application/vnd.docker.image.rootfs.diff.tar.gzip",
     "size": 3121, <----- HAVE NOT ROOT CAUSED WHY A CLIENT WOULD *NOT* SEND THIS
     "digest": "sha256:aba366f7e0be39a4c0e8a1245a676c7f4b91ba79757f3a3222fcd6e978cc6703"
   },

Clients definitely should be sending that layer size.

I'm wondering if it not being sent was a client incorrectly handling the invalid range response (off-by-one) we were sending back when it uploaded the layer.  It does seem we have some evidence that the registry sending back invalid things can trigger the client into then sending back more invalid things.  That's my theory.

This was just so that if somebody found this client they could flip a config switch to get things working again -- but we still should look into it and root cause it; either we or the client are wrong

I don't have podman in my setup, yet.  I'll try to figure out testing with that; if we are happy that covers everything we can drop the flag.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Is there any more context about this? Seems like something we should at least discuss in scrum? Is this related to the discussion we had on the last tripleo irc meeting about queens/stein and moving independent?

I don't think we've reached conclusions about the way forward, at least, I told folks in that irc meeting that they would get another chance to voice concerns. For example it isn't clear if we want to keep queens upstream (I would say no, we should just add that coverage downstream). 

Once we retire older branches stein and queens (assuming we don't keep Q), then we move our repos to independent and then we can consider moving Victoria/Ussuri to EOL - possibly earlier than upstream. At *that* point we reduce our coverage?

It's not directly related to last discussions, this is about running too much non-valuable jobs on CI repos which prevents from merging code, especially where CI is not so stable. There are 5 branches checked here for **CI code** and it's completely redundant checks. It's more related to TripleO reduce load task.
I personally don't see reasons to start wide discussions about this patch because it reduces load from CI repos only, but if anyone wants - let it be.
ack thanks for the clarification and the discussion today in scrum call

environments/ceph-ansible/ceph-ansible.y.message:
ceph-ansible is used in much more than just edge. This should be in an edge related deployment file. Please don't make this change here.

e.g. https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/environments/dcn-hci.yaml#L50

> It's about nova RBD working better when NovaEnableRbdBackend is set per role instead of globally.

Yes, "per role". Why not use ceph-ansible-per-role for those types of deployments?

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/environments/ceph-ansible/ceph-ansible-per-role.yaml

 > The param tells glance to expose the direct backend uris to nova.

Yes, we want COW boots so we want Nova to get the RBD URI, (e.g. rbd://d25504ce-459f-432d-b6fa-79854d786f2b/images/8083c7e7-32d8-4f7a-b1da-0ed7884f1076/snap) so it's not pulled from the glance API.

 > It is another magic setting for glance that gets enabled when
 > NovaEnableRbdBackend: true and GlanceBackend: rbd are set.

Right that's why we still get the COW boots as per:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/stable/train/deployment/glance/glance-api-container-puppet.yaml#L313-L322

 > i.e:
 > 
 > parameter_defaults:
 > NovaEnableRbdBackend: true
 > 
 > is currently equivalent to this:
 > 
 > parameter_defaults:
 > # default to local ephemeral
 > NovaEnableRbdBackend: false
 > GlanceShowMultipleLocations: true
 > ComputeParameters:
 > # Just this role uses RBD for ephemeral
 > NovaEnableRbdBackend: true
 > 
 > 
 > Explicitly setting the param here means we no longer rely on
 > implicit magic and usage is more obvious i.e this just works:
 > 
 > parameter_defaults:
 > NovaEnableRbdBackend: false
 > ComputeParameters:
 > NovaEnableRbdBackend: true

So if you want to do that, you can use per-role or override it separately in another env file.

This has nothing to do with edge.

It's about nova RBD working better when NovaEnableRbdBackend is set per role instead of globally.

The param tells glance to expose the direct backend uris to nova. It is another magic setting for glance that gets enabled when NovaEnableRbdBackend: true and GlanceBackend: rbd are set. 

i.e:

    parameter_defaults:
      NovaEnableRbdBackend: true

is currently equivalent to this:

    parameter_defaults:
      # default to local ephemeral
      NovaEnableRbdBackend: false
      GlanceShowMultipleLocations: true
      ComputeParameters:
        # Just this role uses RBD for ephemeral
        NovaEnableRbdBackend: true


Explicitly setting the param here means we no longer rely on implicit magic and usage is more obvious i.e this just works:

    parameter_defaults:
      NovaEnableRbdBackend: false
      ComputeParameters:
        NovaEnableRbdBackend: true
